claim: The cost of food in Canada has decreased since 1970.

supporting.text: Inflation-adjusted data from Statistics Canada shows that the average cost of food in Canada has increased since 1970.

attacks.text: Inflation-adjusted data from Statistics Canada shows that the average cost of food in Canada has increased since 1970.
The inflation adjustment methodology may not fully account for changes in food quality, variety, and accessibility since 1970.
Statistics Canada's methodology is widely accepted and accounts for quality adjustments through hedonic regression techniques.
Regional variations in food costs may mean that while the national average increased, some areas saw decreases.
National averages are the standard metric for such comparisons, and regional variations do not negate the overall trend.

supporting.text: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) for food, as reported by the Bank of Canada, indicates a steady rise in food prices over the past five decades.

attacks.text: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) for food, as reported by the Bank of Canada, indicates a steady rise in food prices over the past five decades.
The CPI does not account for changes in food quality or variety, which may offset perceived price increases.
Even with quality improvements, inflation-adjusted data still shows a net increase in food costs.
Household income growth has outpaced food price inflation, making food effectively more affordable.
Income inequality means this affordability doesn't apply uniformly across all socioeconomic groups.

supporting.text: Economic studies on purchasing power demonstrate that Canadians spend a higher percentage of their income on food today compared to 1970.

attacks.text: Economic studies on purchasing power demonstrate that Canadians spend a higher percentage of their income on food today compared to 1970.
The percentage of income spent on food does not necessarily reflect the absolute cost, as incomes may have risen faster than food prices.
Inflation-adjusted data shows that the real cost of many staple foods has decreased due to technological advancements in agriculture.
Food price indices indicate nominal prices have increased significantly since 1970, even if relative affordability has changed.
Nominal price increases are largely due to currency inflation and do not reflect real purchasing power changes.

supporting.text: Global trends in agricultural production costs and supply chain expenses have contributed to higher food prices worldwide, including in Canada.

attacks.text: Global trends in agricultural production costs and supply chain expenses have contributed to higher food prices worldwide, including in Canada.
Technological advancements in agriculture have significantly increased efficiency and reduced production costs over time.
Despite technological advancements, rising energy and labor costs have offset many of the efficiency gains in agriculture.
Canada's domestic food production has grown faster than demand, leading to lower relative prices compared to global averages.
Canada's reliance on imported food items means global price trends still heavily influence domestic food costs.

supporting.text: Government reports on household expenditures show that nominal food prices have consistently risen since 1970, without significant periods of decline.

attacks.text: Government reports on household expenditures show that nominal food prices have consistently risen since 1970, without significant periods of decline.
While nominal prices have risen, inflation-adjusted (real) food costs may have decreased due to higher incomes and productivity gains in agriculture.
Inflation adjustments do not account for changes in food quality, variety, or accessibility, which may offset perceived cost reductions.
Government reports may exclude informal or non-market food sources (e.g., home gardens, bartering), which could reduce effective costs.
Informal food sources represent a small fraction of total consumption and are unlikely to significantly alter overall cost trends.
